items.title: Remembering Scott Allen
items.description:
Hey everyone,

Welcome to another great issue this week!

Since the last issue, sad news reached us here at WeeklyXamarin HQ, about the passing of K. Scott Allen. Scott was an infamous Pluralsight course author, who helped so many developers with his courses on C#. He was also a speaker, mentor, fellow Microsoft MVP and very popular in the community.

The tributes pouring in have shown just how respected and liked he was, and how much he has influenced people in their careers. Thank you for everything Scott!

Whatever you get up to this weekend, have a great time and see you next week!

Luce ðŸ§¡
items.description_markdown:
Hey everyone,

Welcome to another great issue this week!

Since the last issue, sad news reached us here at WeeklyXamarin HQ, about the passing of [K. Scott Allen](https://twitter.com/OdeToCode). Scott was an infamous Pluralsight course author, who helped so many developers with his courses on C#. He was also a speaker, mentor, fellow Microsoft MVP and very popular in the community.

The tributes pouring in have shown just how respected and liked he was, and how much he has influenced people in their careers. Thank you for everything Scott! 

Whatever you get up to this weekend, have a great time and see you next week!

Luce ðŸ§¡

items.title: Learn how to get the most out of Xamarin.Forms
TaskLoaderView 2.0: Let's burn IsBusy=true!
items.description:
The related talk to this post from Xamarin Expert Day this year, was in fact on at the same time as my talk so I never got to see it. So I am really excited to see Jean-Marie has created a blog post all about it!

items.description_markdown:

items.title: Launch Icon Badge
items.description:
When you develop a mobile application you always have different versions and each one has a specific environment. During the entire life of your project you switch between each version to try new features or to correct some bugs. Damien has created an extension for Azure DevOps that lets you clearly tell which version of the app is which, from it's launch icon.

Launch Icon Badge by Damien Aicheh
items.description_markdown:
When you develop a mobile application you always have different versions and each one has a specific environment. During the entire life of your project you switch between each version to try new features or to correct some bugs. Damien has created an extension for Azure DevOps that lets you clearly tell which version of the app is which, from it's launch icon.

[**Launch Icon Badge**](https://damienaicheh.github.io/tools/2020/01/09/tool-easily-differentiate-versions-of-your-applications-using-azure-devops-en.html) by [Damien Aicheh](https://twitter.com/DamienAicheh)

items.title: Mobile - Analyse your application network
items.description:
Most mobile applications require network connection. Unfortunately, analysing calls is not so easy. If you want to know more about the calls being made, errors or performance, this post can help!

Mobile - Analyse your application network by John Thiriet
items.description_markdown:
Most mobile applications require network connection. Unfortunately, analysing calls is not so easy. 
If you want to know more about the calls being made, errors or performance, this post can help!

[**Mobile - Analyse your application network**](https://johnthiriet.com/mobile-analyse-app-network/) by [John Thiriet](https://twitter.com/johnthiriet)

items.title: Tips and Tricks for XAML Hot Reload
items.description:
XAML Hot Reload for Xamarin.Forms has been out for a while now in GA. It's an excellent way to massively speed up your UI development. Maddy has some Tips and Tricks to get you started!

Tips and Tricks for XAML Hot Reload by Maddy Leger
items.description_markdown:
XAML Hot Reload for Xamarin.Forms has been out for a while now in GA. It's an excellent way to massively speed up your UI development. Maddy has some Tips and Tricks to get you started!

[**Tips and Tricks for XAML Hot Reload**](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/xamarin/tips-tricks-xaml-hot-reload/) by [Maddy Leger](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/xamarin/author/malegermicrosoft-com/)

embedded_links.title: **Tips and Tricks for XAML Hot Reload**

items.title: DevOps for Android App Bundles
items.description:
Android App Bundle is a new app packaging format from Google for Android applications that dramatically reduces the install size for end users. Traditionally, when building an Android app, one would create one large APK file that all users would receive.

DevOps for Android App Bundles by James Montemagno
items.description_markdown:
Android App Bundle is a new app packaging format from Google for Android applications that dramatically reduces the install size for end users. Traditionally, when building an Android app, one would create one large APK file that all users would receive.

[**DevOps for Android App Bundles**](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/xamarin/android-app-bundles-azure-devops/) by [James Montemagno](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/xamarin/author/jamesmontemagno/)

items.title: Xamarin Forms Tips: Navigate to a Page and Wait Results
items.description:
In Xamarin.Forms, you can navigate asynchronously to a page or a modal. With the Xamarin.Forms Shell, you can perform URL navigation and even pass parameters to the page or the pageâ€™s View Model. But once you navigate to this page or modal and it completes the processing for which it was called, how do you return directly a result to the underlying layer which called the page?

Xamarin Forms Tips, Navigate to a Page and Wait Results by Damien Doumer
items.description_markdown:
In Xamarin.Forms, you can navigate asynchronously to a page or a modal. With the Xamarin.Forms Shell, you can perform URL navigation and even pass parameters to the page or the pageâ€™s View Model. But once you navigate to this page or modal and it completes the processing for which it was called, how do you return directly a result to the underlying layer which called the page?

[**Xamarin Forms Tips, Navigate to a Page and Wait Results**](https://doumer.me/xamarin-forms-tips-navigate-to-a-page-and-wait-results/) by [Damien Doumer](https://twitter.com/Damien_Doumer)

embedded_links.title: **Xamarin Forms Tips, Navigate to a Page and Wait Results**

items.title: Introducing Xamarin.Forms Date Picker
items.description:
Paul Anderson from Syncfusion is back with another great post on a new component from their Essential Studio 2019 Volume 4. This time it is Date Picker!

items.title: Simplifying Visual State Manager with TargetName
items.description:
The Visual State Manager (VSM) has been around for a while now. Since Xamarin.Forms 3.0 in fact! But some exciting improvements to it are coming to Xamarin.Forms 4.5. In his first post on the official blog, Gerald talks you through these changes and how to get started!

Simplifying Visual State Manager with TargetName by Gerald Versluis
items.description_markdown:
The Visual State Manager (VSM) has been around for a while now. Since Xamarin.Forms 3.0 in fact! But some exciting improvements to it are coming to Xamarin.Forms 4.5. In his first post on the official blog, Gerald talks you through these changes and how to get started!

[**Simplifying Visual State Manager with TargetName**](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/xamarin/visual-state-manager/) by [Gerald Versluis](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/xamarin/author/geraldversluis/)

items.title: Sign in with Apple in Xamarin Forms
items.description:
iOS 13 added the ability to sign in with Apple. But how do you do this from your Xamarin code? Rendy aka XamBoy shows you how!

Sign in with Apple in Xamarin Forms by Rendy Del Rosario
items.description_markdown:
iOS 13 added the ability to sign in with Apple. But how do you do this from your Xamarin code?
Rendy aka XamBoy shows you how!

[**Sign in with Apple in Xamarin Forms**](https://www.xamboy.com/2020/01/13/sign-in-with-apple-in-xamarin-forms/) by [Rendy Del Rosario](https://twitter.com/rdelrosario)

embedded_links.title: **Sign in with Apple in Xamarin Forms**

items.title: Device Display Information (Xamarin.Essentials API of the Week) | The Xamarin Show
items.description:
Xamarin.Essentials provides developers with cross-platform APIs for their mobile applications. On this week's Xamarin.Essential API of the week we take a look at the Device Display API that enables you to get information about the current display of the device. This include size, orientation, and a lot more.

Device Display Information (Xamarin.Essentials API of the Week) by Xamarin Show
items.description_markdown:
Xamarin.Essentials provides developers with cross-platform APIs for their mobile applications. On this week's Xamarin.Essential API of the week we take a look at the Device Display API that enables you to get information about the current display of the device. This include size, orientation, and a lot more.

[**Device Display Information (Xamarin.Essentials API of the Week)**](https://channel9.msdn.com/Shows/XamarinShow/Device-Display-Information-XamarinEssentials-API-of-the-Week) by [Xamarin Show](https://channel9.msdn.com/Shows/XamarinShow)

items.title: Partly Cloudy Episode 8 Recap: Mostly Cloudy (CDN & Front Door)
items.description:
Welcome back to Partly Cloudy! The show where you learn how to build a cloud-connected Xamarin mobile application. We start from nothing and don't quit until it's ready for the App Store!
